posts.post_content:
Add another card to the turn-1 land enchantment list: outclasses [Lush Growth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lush Growth), but comparing it to [Utopia Sprawl](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Utopia Sprawl) and [Wild Growth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wild Growth) is tough because they're clearly for a different type of deck.  
  
Enchantress decks running more than a couple colors might enjoy this one a lot, though. More cards! Plus this one's beautiful for mana-fixing in pauper.
posts.html:
Add another card to the turn-1 land enchantment list: outclasses Lush Growth, but comparing it to Utopia Sprawl and Wild Growth is tough because they're clearly for a different type of deck.

Enchantress decks running more than a couple colors might enjoy this one a lot, though. More cards! Plus this one's beautiful for mana-fixing in pauper.

posts.post_content:
Pretty sweet mana fixer, played with it alot at the prerelease today. The cantrip is icing on the cake. One of my favorite cards in the set. It let me get my [Sigarda, Host of Herons](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sigarda, Host of Herons) out on multiple occasions.  
  
However, alot of people are misunderstanding this card. Please don't make the mistake of thinking this ramps your mana like [wild growth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=wild growth). It doesn't.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
This aura also removes the problem of certain lands that:  
  
1) Cannot tap for mana, such as search lands and Glacial Chasm, to name two.  
2) Have penalty for tapping mana, like Ancient Tomb and such.  
  
Simply put, turns a land into a City of Brass without the damage.
posts.html:

Posted By: Gear61 (4/29/2012 12:31:33 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Cantrippers also benefit you if you have a super awesome card that you would want to run 5 (or more) of in your deck (but are obviously not allowed to). A deck with four manamorphose is effectively a 56 card deck.
  
   
One mana-cantrippers (like this card) can also help out this way, provided that you can spare the mana. It's a bonus when the card gives you a nice effect, like filtering for any coloured mana you like.
  
   
Fibonacci
posts.html:
Cantrippers also benefit you if you have a super awesome card that you would want to run 5 (or more) of in your deck (but are obviously not allowed to). A deck with four manamorphose is effectively a 56 card deck.

One mana-cantrippers (like this card) can also help out this way, provided that you can spare the mana. It's a bonus when the card gives you a nice effect, like filtering for any coloured mana you like.

Fibonacci

posts.post_content:
Usually better than [Mana Cylix](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Cylix), and a cheaper version of [Prophetic Prism](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Prophetic Prism). However, the ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) versus ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol) is hard to argue: Prophetic can go into any deck, while this is limited to something with Green.   
Mind you, when going 5 colours, green's you more common colour (for ramping reasons).   
  
Not bad at all, but nothing special in limited. The cantrip is all you can add to something like this.
posts.html:

Posted By: jm00789 (11/7/2012 1:33:59 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Strictly better then the first ideration of [think twice](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=think twice). lol jk but, seriously.  
  
Pulling a [Evolving Wilds](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Evolving Wilds)/[Terramorphic Expanse](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Terramorphic Expanse) in my opening hand I always felt cheated out of a card and it disrupted my tempo. With this, you get better color fixing (because it turns a basic land into a dual land as opposed to fetches a basic land) and it gets replaced by a nicer, more optimistic card for the low CMC of ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol). As long as this in standard I will never play fetch lands for mana fixing in green EVER again. While it's job isn't exciting, it does it REALLY well. I see this getting more play when Ravinica comes out, especially in 3-5 color decks. Imagine how crazy this would have been during alara in 3 color cascade decks. Not to mention the random rare lands that do crazy stuff but unfortunately can only tap for ![1](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=1&type=symbol). Lets green splash a color for a playset of 1 card without splitting up more lands. Good job R&D \*claps\*
